http://tdwg-rdf.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/file/tdwg-logo.png  [http://www.tdwg.org/ http://www.tdwg.org]

=Examples of Darwin Core as RDF using !BiSciCol object properties=

*Date:* (Created) 2013-07-01; (Last modified) 2013-07-01

*Status:* Not part of any standard ([http://www.tdwg.org/standards/147/ Type 3] document); intended to complement the RDF Guide of the Darwin Core Standard ([http://www.tdwg.org/standards/450/])

*Permanent URL:* http://

*TDWG Task Group:* [http://code.google.com/p/tdwg-rdf/ TDWG RDF/OWL Task Group]

*Contributors:* [mailto:steve.baskauf@vanderbilt.edu?subject=RDFguide Steve Baskauf] (TDWG RDF/OWL Task Group)

*Abstract:* These examples follow the Darwin Core RDF Guide. They assume the data model of !BiSciCol (http://biscicol.blogspot.com/ ) and use its object properties to link the class instances.  

http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by/3.0/88x31.png Licensed under [http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/deed Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 License]

*Table of Contents:*
<wiki:toc max_depth="4" />

== 1 A specimen and its associated occurrence ==

This is a relatively simple example where an Occurrence is documented by a single PreservedSpecimen.  The BiSciCol data model is described at http://biscicol.blogspot.com/2013_03_01_archive.html and the BiSciCol terms are described at http://biscicol.org/terms/index.html .  In this example, the Event and Location instances are identified using the BCID system described at http://biscicol.blogspot.com/2013/05/sneak-peeks-biscicol-style.html .

This RDF is structured using BiSciCol object properties as described at http://biscicol.blogspot.com/2013_03_01_archive.html

Note: this example does not include an instance of Geological Context
-->
